title: 107_s1686
content: The Act titled "Safe Nursing and Patient Care Act of 2001" is cited as the short title. The Congress finds that higher nurse staffing levels lead to better patient outcomes, but there are challenges in recruiting and retaining nursing staff. About 500,000 licensed nurses are not practicing nursing due to job dissatisfaction and overtime work. Approximately 500,000 licensed nurses are not practicing nursing due to job dissatisfaction and mandatory overtime, leading to fatigue and compromising patient safety. Limitations on mandatory overtime for nurses will ensure patient safety, quality healthcare services, and aid in nurse retention and recruitment. SEC. 3. LIMITATIONS ON MANDATORY OVERTIME FOR NURSES. Provider Agreements under the Social Security Act are amended to include compliance with limitations on mandatory overtime for nurses. The Social Security Act now includes limitations on mandatory overtime for nurses, prohibiting them from working beyond scheduled shifts or more than 12 hours in a 24-hour period or 80 hours in a consecutive 14-day period, with some exceptions. The Social Security Act limits mandatory overtime for nurses to 12 hours in a 24-hour period or 80 hours in a consecutive 14-day period, with exceptions during declared states of emergency for providers of services expected to deliver an exceptional level of medical care to the community. During a declared state of emergency, a nurse can only be required to work beyond the usual limits if the provider has tried to find alternative staffing and the work requirement ends when the state of emergency is over. During a declared state of emergency, a nurse can file a complaint against a provider for violations related to work requirements. During a state of emergency, a nurse can file a complaint with the Secretary against a provider for violating work requirements. The Secretary will investigate these complaints. During a state of emergency, nurses can file complaints with the Secretary against providers for violating work requirements. The Secretary will investigate these complaints and may require providers to establish a plan of action to address violations, including the possibility of civil money penalties. Nurses are protected from discrimination by providers of services. During a state of emergency, nurses can file complaints with the Secretary against providers for violating work requirements. The Secretary may investigate and penalize providers for violations, including civil money penalties. Nurses are protected from discrimination by providers of services, including penalties for refusing mandatory overtime. During a state of emergency, nurses can report violations to regulatory agencies or management personnel. They can also participate in investigations concerning the matters covered by this subsection. During a state of emergency, nurses can report violations to regulatory agencies or management personnel, participate in investigations, and discuss violations with other employees or healthcare professional associations. Providers of services are prohibited from retaliatory reporting. A nurse may not be reported for refusing mandatory overtime, as it is considered retaliatory reporting. Nurses are deemed to be acting in good faith if they believe the information reported is true and a violation has occurred. Each provider of services must post a notice specifying nurses' rights, including the ability to file a complaint with the Secretary against any provider who violates those rights. A nurse may file a complaint with the Secretary against a provider of services who violates the provisions, and information on how to file such a complaint. Providers of services must regularly post nurse schedules for the department or unit involved. The Secretary may impose a civil money penalty of up to $10,000 for each knowing violation of the nurse schedule posting provisions by a provider of services. More severe penalties can be imposed for patterns of violations. The Secretary may impose more severe civil money penalties for providers who establish patterns of repeated violations of nurse schedule posting provisions. The administration of penalties will follow the same provisions as section 1128A. The Secretary will publish names of providers facing civil money penalties, along with violation details. Penalties imposed under previous ownership will not be disclosed for providers with a change in ownership. After a 1-year period from the change in ownership, penalties imposed on providers will no longer be published by the Secretary. Nurses can voluntarily work more than specified periods as long as it aligns with safe patient care standards. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of mandatory overtime for nurses, which refers to working hours exceeding specified limits that could result in adverse employment consequences if refused. The curr_chunk defines terms related to mandatory overtime for nurses, including adverse employment consequences and the definition of a nurse as a registered nurse or licensed practical nurse. The curr_chunk defines the term 'provider of services' to include various healthcare facilities such as hospitals, outpatient departments, ambulatory surgical centers, and clinics. The term 'declared state of emergency' refers to an officially designated state of emergency declared by the Federal Government or the head of the appropriate State or local governmental agency. The locality is in a state of emergency, excluding emergencies from labor disputes or understaffing in the healthcare industry. The term 'standards of safe patient care' refers to professional standards for nurses. The amendments will take effect one year after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. REPORTS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study to establish safe working hour standards for nurses providing patient care, considering various factors like provider type, department, duties, and shifts. The Director may contract with an eligible entity to carry out a study on appropriate standards of maximum work hours for nurses. A report with recommendations must be submitted to Congress within 2 years. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will conduct a study on overtime practices for nurses in federally operated medical facilities to assess compliance with the Social Security Act. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will submit a report to Congress on the study of overtime practices for nurses in federally operated medical facilities, including hospitals, clinics, and home health care clinics operated by various government departments. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will report to Congress on a study regarding overtime practices for nurses in federally operated medical facilities, with recommendations for policy implementation consistent with section 1866(j).
